Tullio-Altan, a distinguished Italian sociologist, attributes the eclipse of communal republicanism, and the socioeconomic progress it had spawned, to the Counter-Reformation, which shielded Italy from the influence of the Protestant ethic that linked individual salvation and social responsibility. A fuller historical account would obviously also have to take account of the shift of trade routes from the Mediterranean to the Atlantic, among many other factors
